meanings.def: to turn round and round quickly; to make something do this
examples: (+ adv./prep.) The plane was spinning out of control.
a spinning ice skater
My head is spinning (= I feel as if my head is going round and I can't balance).
spin round/around The dancers spun round and round.
spin something (round/around) to spin a ball/coin/wheel
We placed our bets and the croupier spun the roulette wheel.
The Earth spins on its axis once every 24 hours.
The blade spins very fast.
The car spun out of control.
The dinghy spun like a top and a huge wave came at me.
The wheel can now spin freely.
The wine made my head spin.
Jo spun the chair round.
She spun the roulette wheel one last time.
The Earth spins around a central axis.
They spun a coin to see who should go first.

meanings.def: to turn round quickly once; to make somebody do this
examples: He spun around to face her.
She spun on her heel and walked out.
Spin your partner around.
She spun round to see him grinning at her.
He spun the child roughly around.

meanings.def: to make thread from wool, cotton, silk, etc. by twisting it
examples: She sat by the window spinning.
spin something to spin and knit wool
spin A into B spinning silk into thread
spin B from A spinning thread from silk

meanings.def: to produce thread from its body to make a web or cocoon
examples: a spider spinning a web
A silkworm spins a cocoon that can yield 800 metres of pure silk.
They went spinning along the roads on their bikes.

meanings.def: to remove the water from clothes that have just been washed, in a spin dryer
to present information or a situation in a particular way, especially one that makes you or your ideas seem good
examples: An aide was already spinning the senator's defeat as ‘almost as good as an outright win’.

meanings.def: your head feels as though it is going round and round and you cannot balance, especially because you are ill or confused or have had a shock; to make you feel like this
examples: Her head was spinning from the pain.
His theories on economics are enough to make your head spin.

meanings.def: to try to make somebody believe a long story that is not true
to turn around suddenly so that you are facing in the opposite direction
examples: He turned on his heel and marched away angrily.

idioms.idiom: your head is spinning | make your head spin
idioms.def: your head feels as though it is going round and round and you cannot balance, especially because you are ill or confused or have had a shock; to make you feel like this
examples: Her head was spinning from the pain.
His theories on economics are enough to make your head spin.

idioms.def: to try to make somebody believe a long story that is not true
to turn around suddenly so that you are facing in the opposite direction
examples: He turned on his heel and marched away angrily.
Only in the last 50 years have we had clocks accurate enough to measure changes in the earth's spin.
He lost everything on the spin of a roulette wheel.
The dance was full of twists and spins.
Give the washing a short spin.
We calculated the rate of spin.
Give the clothes another spin.
We stopped the washing machine before the spin cycle.

meanings.def: if an aircraft goes into a spin, it falls and turns round rapidly
examples: He had to stop the helicopter from going into a spin.
(figurative) The president's death sent the stock market into a spin.

meanings.def: a short ride in a car for pleasure
examples: Let's go for a spin.
He asked if he could take the car for a spin.

meanings.def: the way you make a ball turn very fast when you throw it or hit it
examples: She puts a lot of spin on the ball.
a spin bowler (= in cricket, a bowler who uses spin)
How do you put more spin on the ball?

meanings.def: a way of presenting information or a situation in a particular way, especially one that makes you or your ideas seem good
examples: Politicians put their own spin on the economic situation.
the government's spin machine
government spin doctors
The chairman tried to put a positive spin on the closure of the factory.
The film retells the famous legend with a Marxist spin.
She's put a whole new spin on the theme of corporate greed.
Her resignation put her colleagues in a spin.
Her resignation put her colleagues in a spin.
